instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00145: What is 820-00145? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00145</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: The device is charging, but the USB is not working. The USB voltage indicator does not light up at all. I tried using a flash drive, but its light is also not turning on, indicating that there is no USB 5V power. Where should I check next? I have already tested the DC socket and the intermediate flex cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00145</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: By the way, I tested it using a USB-C to USB converter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00145</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: On the J4700, pins 2 and 52 should have a stable voltage of 5V. The fluctuation you are experiencing, ranging from 0.80V to 1.1V, suggests that there may be an issue with the power supply or the circuitry related to those pins. It is important for these pins to have a consistent 5V voltage for proper USB functionality. I recommend further troubleshooting or consulting a technician to diagnose and resolve the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00145</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: "The voltage value on pins 2 and 52 of the J4700 is not stable; it fluctuates between 0.80V, 0.90V, and 1.1V. Shouldn't there be a constant 5V here?"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00145</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
I suppose you have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board in fact.

An USB device is powered from L7850; through <CHIP>U7860</CHIP>/65, depending which way the device is connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00145</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Yes

<SIGNAL>PP5V1_S4SW</SIGNAL> : 5 volt
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_S4SW_CC1</SIGNAL>/CC2   :   not stable; it fluctuates between 0.80V, 0.90V, and 1.1V. 
<CHIP>U7860</CHIP> Is the <CHIP>U7860</CHIP> faulty?

If I jumper between <SIGNAL>PP5V1_S4SW</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V1_S4SW_CC1</SIGNAL> will it work?
Will it work if I connect <SIGNAL>PP5V1_S4SW</SIGNAL> with <SIGNAL>PP5V1_S4SW_C</SIGNAL>?  :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00145</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Only one of <CHIP>U7860</CHIP>/65 works at a time; depending of the connection way.

Check <SIGNAL>BBPD_VCONN1</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>2_EN</SIGNAL> signals.
At least one should be high, when external USB device is connected.
If not, change <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>.

If use USB-C hub, then power it externally.
